snippet.title: Amplifying Global South Voices for Science and Innovation
snippet.description: Our new expanded mandate focuses on improving food security, accelerating climate action, and promoting access to healthcare across the global South.

snippet.title: BT COTTON STORY  IN MWEA
snippet.description: Here is the story of BT Cotton Farmers in Mwea. Bt Cotton is early maturing, flowering at three months, and ready for harvest at about five months. Bt variety can survive on less rainfall than its conventional counterpart. The big difference is seen at harvest. Farmers growing conventional cotton will yield 500 to 700kg per acre, while those growing Bt cotton harvest 1,500 to 2,000 kg from the same acre. With a kilogram of cotton going for ksh50, a Bt cotton farmer will earn ksh75,000 (US$656) — triple the amount earned by his conventional counterpart.

snippet.title: SCIENCE BARAZA EPISODE 2 DR.  ROSE MWEBAZA
snippet.description: Women at the center of environmental governance: Africa is the largest region in the UN environment systems and yet it often has the softest voice. This episode features Dr. Rose Mwebaza, Director and Regional Representative of UNEP Africa Office. Dr. Mwebaza is critical in shaping African Environmental policy at UNEP, the world's leading environmental body based in Nairobi, Kenya; she also represents Africa in all the multilateral process at the UN environment fund. Here she explains the key institutional drivers of environmental policy in Africa, amplifying Africa's voice, and raising the status of the continent within UN systems.

Alliance for Science is hosting  studio discussions with guests and interacting with team members attending the conference to highlight  major issues around this event to connect them with #climateaction  activities in Africa

Through the #Relief2Resilience campaign Alliance for Science is committed to supporting local communities in developing climate-smart solutions and biotechnological developments that contribute to solving issues.

snippet.title: Resilience and Innovation Among Maasai community.
snippet.description:
Exploring the inspiring stories of a group of Maasai farmers in different parts of Kajiado County, Kenya, as they confront the devastating effects of drought on their livestock and livelihoods. Traditionally dependent on cattle for food and survival, they found themselves facing a significant reduction in their herds due to the prolonged dry spells. 

The documentary begins by painting a vivid picture of the lush grasslands that once nurtured their livestock, symbolizing abundance and prosperity. However, a changing climate has resulted in recurrent droughts, leaving the once-verdant landscapes barren and parched, resulting in to decrease in food for their livestock.

With intimate interviews and stunning visuals, the documentary introduces viewers to the Maasai community, highlighting their deep connection to the land and their resilient spirit. Despite the challenges they face, the farmers refuse to surrender to despair and instead embark on a courageous journey to adapt and find sustainable solutions. 

Narrated by local community members of Siana Women’s Group, Matonyok Women’s Group, Oltiyani Youth Group, and Mr. Fred Waiganjo, this heartwarming story showcases the farmers' collective efforts to rehabilitate their grasslands. We see how they have begun to embrace new farming techniques, learning about new ways of cattle keeping, and the cultivation of drought-resistant grass and crops. Through their innovative approaches, they hope to secure a better future for their families and protect their remaining cattle. 

Along the journey, our audience will witness the struggles and triumphs of the farmers. From community-led initiatives to resource-sharing, Government initiatives, and support, the Maasai farmers come together, building a strong support system that empowers them to overcome adversity. It also highlights the need for improved access to resources, education, and government support to sustain their progress and amplify their impact. 

It concludes on a hopeful note, showcasing the positive transformation brought about by the farmers' determination and adaptability. It celebrates their resilience and emphasizes the importance of preserving indigenous knowledge and wisdom in the face of environmental change. 

The Documentary is an eye-opening glimpse into the lives of farmers as they battle the effects of drought, ushering in a new era of sustainable and resilient farming practices. Their stories serve as an inspiration to viewers worldwide, reminding us of the power of grassroots initiatives and community-driven solutions in creating a better future for all.

snippet.title: Recap from our farmers training event in Nairobi Kenya
snippet.description: This training event sought to empower farmers by providing a comprehensive understanding of the potential and applications of innovative agricultural tools including biotechnology. By harnessing the power of biotechnology, farmers can improve crop productivity, reduce environmental impacts, and contribute to sustainable and resilient agriculture in the face of global challenges.

snippet.title: Recap from the Africa Waste is Wealth Conference held from June 6 to 8, 2023 in Nairobi, Kenya
snippet.description: The Africa  waste is wealth conference organized by the non-profit Taka Taka Ni Mali in partnership with Alliance for Science and East African Business Council (EABC) highlighted the need to East African Community member states to harmonize their policies on waste management because there is more value in tackling the problem together as a region.

snippet.title: World Environment Day-  A call for innovative technologies to solve climate change
snippet.description: One of the most pressing challenges we face today is climate change. It poses a significant threat to the well-being of the planet and its inhabitants, making it crucial to adopt innovative technologies to combat this global crisis. Innovative technologies in agriculture can help optimize resource utilization, reduce water consumption, and minimize the use of chemical inputs, thus promoting sustainability #worldenvironmentday2023 #worldenvironmentday #biotechnology #climatechange

snippet.title: International Symposium on Agricultural Transformation and Biotech Crops in Africa
snippet.description:
Alliance for Science, West Africa Center for Crop Improvement (WACCI) - University of Ghana, and Alliance for Science Ghana invite you to participate virtually in the International Symposium on Agricultural Transformation and Biotech Crops in Africa.
 
Based on the theme: Increasing Access to New Tools, Technologies, and Methods in Africa’s Agriculture, the symposium will deliberate on the future of biotech crops in Africa.
 
Participants will discuss how GMOs have been deployed on the African continent for the benefit of farmers, their impact so far, and their prospects. Also, participants will deliberate on the yet-to-be-realized potential that genome editing holds for the ongoing efforts to ensure Africa feeds itself.

Researchers, scientists, academics, industry players, government officials, regulators, and policy experts from all over the world, will be speaking at the symposium.
 
In the end, the symposium will propose pathways to making the African continent food-sufficient, using innovative technologies.
 
Date: Friday, 2nd June 2023
Time: 9 am GMT

snippet.title: Recap from the Farmers Day celebration in Accra, Ghana
Join the movement for a National Farmers Day
snippet.description:
Today, we are commemorating the World Farmers Day, a special occasion to honor and appreciate the hardworking farmers who play a vital role in feeding our global population. 

Join us as we shine a light on the transformative power of innovative technologies and their potential to revolutionize agriculture for a brighter and sustainable future. As we mark the world's hunger day, let us unite in recognizing the pivotal role of farmers and join hands in ensuring access to innovative technologies that can revolutionize agriculture, safeguard our planet, and create a sustainable future for all. Together, we can empower farmers and transform the world of agriculture.  #FuturesThinking

snippet.title: The Cartagena Protocol on Biosafety
AfS Live- Greg Jaffee - ABCs of new bioengineered disclosure requirement in US
snippet.description:
Under the National Bioengineered Food Disclosure Standard, which took effect Jan. 1, the US now requires mandatory bioengineered disclosure on foods containing genetically engineered ingredients.

Join Greg Jaffe, an internationally recognized expert on agricultural biotechnology and biosafety, as he walks us through the ABCs of the new requirement. He’ll share examples from labels he recently found in the grocery store and leave plenty of time for questions.

Greg is the associate director of policy and regulatory affairs for the Alliance for Science, as well as director of the Project on Biotechnology for the Center for Science in the Public Interest (CSPI). He holds a law degree from Harvard Law School and previously served as a trial attorney for the US Department of Justice’s Environmental and Natural Resources Division and as senior counsel with the US Environmental Protection Agency’s Air Enforcement Division.

snippet.title: Ghanaian Youth Debate GMOs
snippet.description: Alliance for Science Ghana and University of Ghana organized a student debate on the pros and cons of adopting GMOs. Students said they learned new things about the technology and dropped some of their misperceptions.

snippet.title: AFS Live -  Food security: Ghanaian scientists on the cutting edge
snippet.description:
Ghana is one of the African countries working to improve food security and agricultural sustainability through scientific research and innovation. A number of public institutions in the country are applying cutting edge tools to improve food staples. In this webinar, four young scientists spearheading cutting-edge research on food security crops in Ghana — Dr. John Elebu, head of cowpea and soybean projects, West African Center for Crop Improvement (WACCI); Dr. Agyemang Danquah, head of tomato genetics program, WACCI; Dr. Mavis Owusuaa, molecular biotechnologist, University of Energy and Natural Resources (UENR); and Dr. Daniel Ofosu, research scientist, Biotechnology and Nuclear Agriculture Research Institute (BNARI), will discuss their research.

The scientists will share why they’re motivated to use innovation to develop high quality, safe and nutritious crops to feed Ghana’s growing population. They will also talk about the challenges they encounter in their research and opportunities going forward for the development of good agricultural systems, improving food security, and promoting agricultural sustainability in the country.

Modesta Abugu, a PhD student in horticultural science and AgBiOFEWS Fellow at North Carolina State University, will be moderating this webinar.

snippet.title: Maci Mueller: Pioneering revolutionary changes in livestock breeding through gene editing
snippet.description: By combining gene editing with other advanced reproductive tools, FFAR Fellow Maci Mueller is seeking to develop an efficient method for distributing the elite genetics and beneficial traits that farmers and ranchers prize. She sees the approach as one way to achieve goals like sustainability, improved animal welfare and food security.

snippet.title: Is Kenya ready for gene editing technology and products?
snippet.description:
Kenya is one of the pioneering African countries gearing up with research on gene edited crops to boost food security. Among the many gene-edited products under research include disease-resistant banana and striga-resistant sorghum. African researchers are using CRISPR gene editing technology to protect these staples against diseases that affect production and livelihood for millions of farmers in Africa.

Join expert panelists Dr. Leena Tripathi, principal scientist in plant biotechnology at the International Institute of Tropical Agriculture (IITA);  Josphat Muchiri, deputy director technical services at Kenya National Biosafety Authority (NBA), and Dr. Steven Runo, principal investigator of striga species on sorghum and associate professor at Kenyatta University as they address questions about Kenya’s readiness to adopt gene editing research and products.  Specifically, they will discuss the potential of genome editing research to improve Kenya’s food security. They will also share insights into the regulatory landscape and public sector perspective in conducting gene editing research.

Doris Wangari, a biotechnology regulatory expert in Kenya, will moderate this event.

snippet.title: CRISPR CAS: A tool for positive change
snippet.description: CRISPR Cas is a powerful tool for positive change in agriculture.

snippet.title: AfS live - Robert Paarlberg - Resetting the table: Straight talk about the food we grow and eat
snippet.description:
Discussions about the future of our food system have never been more polarized and grounded in ideology. Scholar and author Robert Paarlberg offers a bold, science-based corrective to the groundswell of misinformation about food and how it’s produced.

Join AfS managing editor Joan Conrow in a free-ranging conversation with Paarlberg as we talk about how the world can be fed without harming the environment. We’ll discuss food deserts, food swamps, the greening of “industrial farming,” animal welfare, biotechnology, global food markets, the true source of the current obesity crisis, and more. Paarlberg will also offers solutions that can make sense for farmers and consumers alike. His newest book, Resetting the Table, provides a road map through the rapidly changing worlds of food and farming, laying out a practical path to bring the two together.

Robert Paarlberg is an adjunct professor of public policy at the Harvard Kennedy School and an associate at Harvard’s Weatherhead Center. He has been a member of the Board of Agriculture and Natural Resources at the National Research Council, a member of the Board of Directors at Winrock International, and a consultant to the International Food Policy Research Institute, the US Agency for International Development, and the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation. He is the author of Starved for Science, Food Politics, and The United States of Excess, among other works. He lives in Massachusetts.

snippet.description: Biotechnology can be an effective tool for reducing agriculture's climate-warming greenhouse gas emissions while helping farmers adapt to climate change impacts.

snippet.title: AfS Live - New Generation GMOs: The incredible purple tomato
snippet.description: Biotechnology is a powerful tool that is starting to be used for enhancing the nutritional content of fruits and vegetables. One of the first of these new generation crops is the genetically modified purple tomato, improved for higher levels of anthocyanins, a naturally occurring anti-inflammatory compound that protects against various forms of chronic, diet-related human diseases. Join the developer of the purple tomato, Prof. Cathie Martin of the John Innes Centre, as we discuss the science and motivation behind GM purple tomatoes.  Nathan Pumplin of Norfolk Plant Sciences and Eric Ward, president of AgBiome, will discuss the regulatory status and market perspectives of this product, especially with regard to the pending US Department of Agriculture decision on purple tomatoes. Modesta Abugu, a doctoral student in horticultural sciences at North Carolina State University and 2015 Alliance for Science Global Leadership Fellow, will serve as moderator.

snippet.title: Nigeria seed companies gear up for GMO cowpea seeds
snippet.description: The newly-released GMO cowpea is popular with farmers, prompting Nigerian seed companies to step up production to meet the strong demand.

snippet.title: GM crops: Upending the agroecology rhetoric
snippet.description:
According to a recent critique published in Scientific American magazine, “GM crops are rooted in a colonial-capitalist model of agriculture based on theft of Indigenous land and on exploiting farmers’ and food workers’ labor, women’s bodies, Indigenous knowledge and the web of life itself.” The Alliance for Science was singled out as implicated in this supposed model of exploitation. Yet this political rhetoric is itself problematic, obscuring urgent needs to improve food security and tackle environmental challenges and denying the role of science in solving real-world problems. In this live event, our panel of expert fellows — all from the Global South — address head-on the so-called “agroecology” critique and show how critics of biotechnology risk harming the interests of resource-poor farmers in countries like Bangladesh, Kenya and Ghana by denying them access to new tools.

Speakers include Arif Hossain, CEO and Executive Director of Farming Future Bangladesh (FFB); Patricia Nanteza, AfS associate director of training and founder of Science Stories Africa; and Nassib Mugwanya, doctoral candidate of agricultural and extension Education, North Carolina State University. Joseph Gakpo Opoku, journalist from Ghana, will moderate. Note: Dr. Maywa Montenegro de Wi, an agroecology professor and co-author of the critique, was invited to dialogue but she declined.
